title: 107_hr5003
content: The Act titled "Capitol Police Retention, Recruitment, and Authorization Act of 2002" increases the annual rate of basic compensation for Capitol Police officers by 5 percent for fiscal year 2003 and the following 4 years. The increase for officers above the rank of captain is determined at the Board's discretion, not to exceed 5 percent. Newly-appointed members and employees also receive increased rates. The Capitol Police Board can pay newly-appointed officers, members, and civilian employees at a rate higher than the lowest rate for their position, but not exceeding the maximum rate. Additionally, there is provision for additional compensation for specialty assignments. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION FOR SPECIALTY ASSIGNMENTS. Amends Section 909(e) of the Emergency Supplemental Act, 2002 to allow for additional compensation for officers in specialty assignments designated by the chief of the Capitol Police. Removes the cap on the amount of compensation. SEC. 5. Premium pay limits for Capitol Police officers applied annually during emergencies. Effective from September 11, 2001. SEC. 6. Capitol Police officers receive 8 hours of annual leave per pay period after 3 years of employment. SEC. 7. Annuities and pay for reemployed annuitants serving with the Capitol Police. Reemployed annuitants serving as Capitol Police officers are exempt from certain provisions of title 5, United States Code. Individuals receiving annuities based on service after January 1, 2002, are not eligible for this exemption. Reemployed annuitants serving as Capitol Police officers are exempt from certain provisions of title 5, United States Code if they meet specific age or service criteria. This exemption applies to service performed between the enactment of the Act and September 30, 2004. The Capitol Police Board will establish a tuition reimbursement program for officers and members enrolled in higher education programs related to law enforcement. They may also receive bonus payments upon completion of the program. Additionally, bonus payments are available for officers and employees who recruit new officers. SEC. 9. Bonus payments for officers and employees who recruit new officers. The Capitol Police Board may provide a one-time bonus to any officer, member, or civilian employee who recruits someone to serve in the Capitol Police. Any funds from the disposal of Capitol Police property or compensation for damage or loss shall be deposited in the US Treasury for Capitol Police Board expenses. Reimbursements for services provided to governments will also be deposited accordingly. Any funds from reimbursement for assistance provided by the Capitol Police will be deposited in the US Treasury for Capitol Police Board expenses. These funds can be used for any authorized purpose and will remain available until expended, starting from fiscal year 2003. SEC. 11 permits the Capitol Police Board to lease facilities and property for the use of Capitol Police. The Capitol Police Board has the authority to lease facilities and property for the Capitol Police, including securing an interim training facility while the permanent training facility is being completed in Cheltenham, Maryland. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. The Capitol Police Board can request assistance from the Architect of the Capitol for entering into lease agreements as needed. SEC. 12. The total number of full-time positions for the United States Capitol Police is limited to 1,981 positions starting from fiscal year 2002. SEC. 13. The mandatory retirement age is temporarily increased to 59 years during fiscal years 2003 and 2004. SEC. 14. Regulations for the disposal of firearms by Capitol Police officers must be approved by relevant committees. SEC. 15 allows US Capitol Police officers working with police dogs to use official vehicles to transport the dogs between their residence and duty station. SEC. 16 expresses Congress's opinion on the management of Capitol Police. SEC. 16 expresses Congress's opinion that the chief of the Capitol Police should maximize training opportunities for officers and rotate them among different duties to enhance their skills and readiness. SEC. 17 authorizes appropriations for fiscal years to implement this Act. SEC. 18 specifies the effective date. SEC. 18 specifies that this Act and its amendments will apply to pay periods during fiscal year 2003 and beyond.
